Reviews.Title: “Very reasonable no-frills rooms in monastery”
Reviews.Author: bf99
Reviews.Content: Located in a monastery, but with little sign of monks, this place has an ambience closer to a a modern budget hotel. It offers comfortable no-frills accommodation (e.g. modern bathrooms but no TV or kettles in rooms), a good breakfast, and helpful reception staff. It's also very reasonably priced. The building itself has some interesting features, e.g. its modern spiral staircase. It is conveniently located close to the attractive Zattere waterfront and the Accademia bridge, in a pleasant artistic area only slightly off the main tourist trail.

Reviews.Title: “Monestary a surprise”
Reviews.Author: Patricia T
Reviews.Content: My husband expected a musty churchy establishment, but he was pleasantly surprised to find this monestary fully modernized, almost to the point of sterility. It was very clean, the AC worked beautifully, and the elevator worked fine. No TV but who needs it. The reception was friendly and helpful. Breakfast was a bit spartan: no fruit, eggs or meat. It is in the Dorsoduro district, a very short walk from the Grand Canal Accademia vaporetto boat stop and bridge, and the art gallery. It is also a few steps from several waterfront restaurants on the Canale della Giudecca.

Reviews.Title: “Very quiet and spacious place in Venice”
Reviews.Author: heerlyckheid
Reviews.Content: We stayed for two nights in this peaceful place in Venice during the Biennale. It was a very warm period and the center of Venice was crowded, so it was a pleasure to return to this quiet, simple but very nice haven. I would stay here again on a next visit to Venice.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent for the Money”
Reviews.Author: athena-fl
Reviews.Content: We found a room at Don Orione at the last minute when we fled our original hotel with no hot water. The kind staff, the spacious and spotlessly clean room and the low price made us wish we'd stayed here in the first place. Note: Don Orione does not accept walk-ins typically, so if you are thinking of staying here, reserve ahead. The location was very good, just a short walk to the Accademia or the Peggy Guggenheim Collection. The room was bright and airy, very clean and fresh. The bathroom was clean and a nice size. The breakfast was generous, with a large selection of items. The hotel offered free wi-fi and the staff were friendly and helpful. And the price was very reasonable for Venice. We would definitely stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “excellent location”
Reviews.Author: cyborys
Reviews.Content: Best location ever...minutes to either Accademia or Zattere vapporetto stops which together offer options to cover just about all major spots and sights. Good eateries nearby, including a branch of Pizzeria Oche and range of choices in Campo Santa Margherita and Barnabas. On the Zattere, several choices for leisurely coffee and ice cream (Da Nico) indulgences. Great for jogging and walking to take open, fresh air and views on the Giudecca. Rooms clean, staff very welcoming and helpful. Peaceful setting.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent position, great breakfast, go to Accademia ferry stop.”
Reviews.Author: AninaBlueMountains
Reviews.Content: I stayed here a few years back and have visited again since then. It deserves the high ratings others have given it. One travel tip- if you are travelling to and from it for the first time DON'T go to the Zattere vaporetto stop unless you are happy to carry your cases across the bridge- up and down with about 20 steps each side. Instead get the vaporetto up the Grand Canal and get off at Accademia. It is then a flat walk of about 3 minutes maximum with no steps. If you are here in high summer make sure you ask for an air conditioned room and that you have screened windows otherwise those Venetian mosquitos can drive you crazy.

Reviews.Title: “clean, quiet and affordable place to stay in Venice”
Reviews.Author: ParisRoubaix
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed two nights in Venice at this cultural center which previously was used as an orphanage. It was clean, quiet and affordable. Breakfast was more than ample and tasty. Service at the front desk was pleasant and competent.

Reviews.Title: “LARGE AND CLEAN”
Reviews.Author: flzerounian
Reviews.Content: This hotel is a very spacous hotel with large, clean rooms,modern bathrooms and shining floors and hallways. It is very peaceful and quiet ,a place you can meditate in. The staff is great and helpful and professional. The breakfast is more than adequate and tasteful; but most of all, it has the best location in Venice. Only a walking distance from Zattere or Accademia stops and quick to get off the vaporetto and walk to your hotel. The surrounding streets of the hotel is spacious and very safe and peaceful at night. If you are looking to have a good night sleep and yet be close to Piazza San Marco and all the other attractions, this is the hotel to stay at. I rate this hotel 5 star and yet affordable.

Reviews.Title: “Great location away from the crowds”
Reviews.Author: avvirish
Reviews.Content: Although we booked this stay through a convent/monastery booking service, this is far from being either. It has been recently renovated with amenities to match most contemporary hotels. It was easy to reach via the vaporetto from the Santa Lucia train station. Once you arrive at the Zaterre stop, you'll find the monumental facade of the Church of Gesuati just a few steps away. Begin walking along the right-hand side of the church, away from the water. The entrance to the Centro is less than a block behind the church. We were able to reach the hotel with our luggage in tow without much effort. We paid 140 euros ($210 USD) per night for two nights plus a 127 euro ($190) booking/processing fee through monasterystays.com. The rooms are comfortable, with large windows and baths. We arrived on a Saturday evening, and we were given a double room with a private bath and two single beds pushed together. The room was simply furnished and clean, but our sink stopper broke while the sink was full of water. We called the hotel staff but were informed it couldnâ€™t be fixed until Monday morning â€“ they day we were checking out. After a night of using the shower to wash our hands and brush our teeth, we dropped by the front desk the next morning, and they offered to move us to another available room. This time, we were able to request a queen-size bed, which was nice. The dÃ©cor in this wing was a bit different, but still clean. The view was very nice. In my opinion, the breakfast was very disappointing; there wasn't a large selection of food, and they continually ran out of items. The cappuccino was really good, even though it was made by a self-serve machine. The hotel is located not far from a large grocery store, where we purchased snacks. We enjoyed observing the differences between Italian and US markets. Between the grocery and Centro Culturale, there is a great pizzeria that was suggested to us by a person at the front desk; it was full of tourists and locals alike. One of our favorite aspects about this hotel was its location in Dorsoduro, AWAY from the highly touristy areas. It was quiet and relaxing near the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Simple, but very nice and a great location”
Reviews.Author: traveling_foodie1
Reviews.Content: They took us in when the Galleria, just down the street, would not honor our reservation. The rooms were simple but spacious, with bathrooms en suite. There is wi-fi when it works, for a fee. Breakfasts were just fine, and you can take your food into the courtyard and enjoy the morning light. Transportation from the airport is easy via the Alilaguna, and it is very close to the Accademia vaporetto stop. I would be very happy to stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Great!”
Reviews.Author: JannieAnn
Reviews.Content: We loved Venice and stayed at the Don Orione after coming off the Queen Victoria cruise ship. I was looking for cheaper accommodation and checked our the monastery / convent options. Was delighted to come across this one and was sold on it as it looked so clean (and dust-free - important as my daughter has dustmite allergy), without being too stark and impersonal. (My daughter did not sneeze once!) We were very happy with the friendliness and service right from the moment of booking (direct via email). As I asked for a triple room, we were offered the choice of a large double and single or 3 singles. All emailed queries were handled immediately including advice on the best way to get from the ship to the location. And the location is excellent, between Zattere and Accademia. The religious aspect is minimal and the modern design incorporates the sites history. The reception staff are friendly and helpful. We were able to leave our luggage (as we arrived early) and head off for our prebooked Secret Itineraries tour of the Doges Palace (about 5-10 minutes walk or next stop on the waterbus). The only slight drawback was the (continental) breakfast, some fruit would have been nice, but it was enough to see you through until lunch. Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: “A Hotel with a Major Facelift!”
Reviews.Author: Netoy
Reviews.Content: Don't let the category religious place fool you - this is one modern hotel! They had completely renovated the place that it contains state-of-the-art lighting, fixtures, etc. I liked that the hotel is located away from the hub of things. It was quiet, very clean, and spacious. The room that was given to us (there were 3 of us) was big and the bathroom was almost as big as the room itself. The place is also very close to the vaporetto stops (there's 2 - 1 on each side of the hotel). There are also restaurants near the area. This hotel is located just one stop away from Piazza San Marco and the Basilica. Highly recommended!!

Reviews.Title: “Convenient and comfortable”
Reviews.Author: Duettist96
Reviews.Content: It is true that the rooms are 'minimalist' - no TV, radio or other unnecessary fripperies of any kind here! - but they are spotlessly clean and very comfortable. We were with a group of friends and were probably, therefore, in the room less than usual - going out at 0930 and often not back before 2330. Breakfast was more than adequate with cereal, fruit, pastries, bread and yoghourt. The staff were wonderful; nothing was too much trouble in terms of finding information or making suggestions. We were all Christians from the same parish, but even a non-religious person would be more than happy here. Religion is not overt but is a constant presence in terms of the courtesy, kindness and simplicity shown by everyone at the centre. If you do not like a crucifix on the bedroom wall, best not come here, it's true! The location is perfect - halfway between the Grand Canal and the Giudecca canal, one minute's walk from Accademia and Zattere vaporetto stops. For our silver wedding last Octber, we arrived by Orient Express and stayed in the utterly peerless Il Bauer Palazzo. That can't be beaten. HOWEVER, we have had just as special an experience this time - simply with less carpet, jacuzzis and fluffy bathrobes. I recommend this place unconditionally.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, atmosphere and staff”
Reviews.Author: DJRTEX
Reviews.Content: Booked based on tripadvisor and travelguide reviews and was very happy. My husband and I stayed for 2 nights in April 2008. Very clean, recently updated with simple decor. Great location, staff and price. If you are looking for simple, safe and affordable accomodations I would recommend.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent stay”
Reviews.Author: reviewer73
Reviews.Content: I highly recommend this centre. As a single female traveler who is transitioning from her hosteling days, I felt very fortunate to have happened upon such excellent accommodation. The centre is a clean, modern facility with a very welcoming staff and a social conscience. It is conveniently located by the Academia Bridge and is steps from the canal. I would definently stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Very Nice Hotel in a Great Location”
Reviews.Author: Wolftrapper
Reviews.Content: I recently stayed at this establishment for 3 nights. The room, and the entire center, was immaculate. Breakfast was provided each morning and was more than sufficient to start the day in Venezia. One outstanding feature of this religious guesthouse is its location. It is a very short walk to two vaporetto stops, Academia on the Grand Canal and Zattere. If you are travelling either too or from the airport, there is also a "boat" stop at Zattere that is just a few steps from the front of the center - very convenient if transporting luggage. There are also many excellent eateries withing walking distance as well as excellent gellato stands. Look for Gellato Nico on the Zattere (just around the corner) for great gellato for only one euro. There is a curfew at the Culturale Centro, as there often is at religious guesthouses. I thought it was 11:30 but found out after I arrived that it was 1:30 a.m. Plenty sufficient to do everything that you want to in Venice. I would, without hesitation, stay at this establishment again if I return to Venice.

Reviews.Title: “Quiet, Comfortable, Clean, Convenient and Affordable”
Reviews.Author: samplin
Reviews.Content: We were booked into the Don Orione for six nights as part of a group. My daughter and I shared a room with two other women. The twin bed was about the most comfortable I had in Italy. The room was large and spotless. We had a huge bathroom with super fixtures. The shower was large enough to accomodate one of our group who was quite tall and sturdily built. The air-conditioning worked really well and the shutters muffled the sounds of church bells in the early morning. The Don Orione is located behind the Church of the Gesuati which is on the Guidecca Canal. It is about 40 yards from the door to the Zattere vaporetto stop with service on two lines. This was really convenient. Along the Zattere Fondamenta are several restaurants with seating either on the shore or on the water. The one closest to the Church has outstanding Tiramisu. Gianni's had good food as well with some really interesting pizza choices. Nico's Bar with its awesome gelato is also along the Fondamenta. It was an every day duty to visit Nico's. Art lovers will enjoy staying at the Don Orione because of its proximity to both the Accademia and the Peggy Guggenheim Museums. The Ca' Rezzonico is easily accesible on foot. We also were able to walk to the Grande Scuola San Rocco and the Frari. The Accademia Vaporetto stop is less than 100 yards from the front door of the Don Orione and provides service to San Marco and all of the treasures to be found in that area. Breakfast was more than adequate, but a bit of protein would have been nice. The Don Orione would be my first choice if I ever have the great fortune to go back to Venice.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, very clean!”
Reviews.Author: WSUCougs
Reviews.Content: I just returned from a three night stay at the Centro Culturale Don Orione Artigianelli in Venice. This faciity has been completely remodeled and everything is new. This is a retreat property, but we would stay again. You cannot beat the location -- either the Accademia (Grand Canal) or Zattere (Guidecca Canal) stops -- no stairs, no small bridges, just a short walk and you are there. It is located on the right side of Gesuati Chiesa off the Zattere stop. The rooms were very clean and spacious, more of a dorm type feel. We were a group of four and we requested four single beds (beds were comfortable, too). Bathroom was spacious with a shower and towel warmer. The property was very quiet and must have sound-proof walls because we rarely heard people coming and going and it was busy (New Year' Eve weekend). There is not a tv in the room, but there is one in the room off of the reception area where you can get CNN. You will not have any great views at this property. We paid 174 euros for a quad room. If you are looking for a clean, convenient, friendly staff, continential breakfast, no street/canal noise type of accomodation this would be a good place to stay.

Reviews.Title: “Away of the hoards of tourists...”
Reviews.Author: Princess T-Rex
Reviews.Content: The Don Orione is one of the most unique places I have ever stayed. Much like a hotel, it is a bit of an experience (in a good way). Conveniently located steps from the Accademia vaporetto stop near the Accedemia bridge this hotel is not far from San Marco Square but is far enough that you won't be fighting hoards of tourists all the time. The rooms in the Don Orione are immaculate and spartan. We had a lovely room overlooking a courtyard. Our bathroom was HUGE but the shower stall was still the tiny little stall that you find all over Italy. The towels here were also unusual (if you are use to terrycloth towels). They are very big but are more like a tablecloth than towels, still they got the job done. The staff is friendly but they do not speak a lot of English. The breakfast room is large and clean. Breakfast was cereals, pastries, breads, juices, teas, and coffee. You must leave your room key at the front desk when you leave the hotel (a fine idea in my book - I can't lose the key that way). There is also a curfew (1 am) which wasn't a problem for us. If you are looking to see the sights in Venice and would like a lovely stay for a very reasonable price away from the hoards, this is the hotel for you.

Reviews.Title: “Great location and great value - clean, simple, and modern”
Reviews.Author: Brad-RDU
Reviews.Content: This is a great place if you're looking for something clean and comfortable while exploring Venice. The rooms are simply furnished and everything is kept very clean. The style is a mix of modern furniture and finishes within a historical building. The staff is very friendly and helpful. The location is great for arrival/departure (a 3 minute walk carrying your luggage from the Zattere stop) and exploring the city (15 minute walk to San Marco and Rialto). I had heard good things about the Dorsoduro neighborhood, where this hotel is located. It's not nearly as crowded as the San Marco area, but is close to the sites. The other posts on this hotel and the hotel website accurately reflect what we found. I would definitely recommend this place and would stay there again. Our room rates were Euro 116/night for a double with private bathroom and Euro 150/night for a triple with a private bathroom. Breakfast was included.

Reviews.Title: “A Warm Welcome in Venice”
Reviews.Author: peony48
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for six nights during the latter part of November, 2005. I chose it because it had been reviewed favorably on several websites I consulted and because the price and the location seemed perfect for me. I e-mailed several months in advance for a reservation, but I think advance notice of that length is not nearly as important during the off-season as during the high season. According to the desk clerk, the Center had been moderately busy the week prior to my arrival. However, it had only five to ten people per night during my visit. It seems to draw an international crowd; I heard English, French, German, and Italian spoken in the breakfast room. The Center is housed in a large, very old, four-storey building on the Rio Terra Marco Foscarini, halfway between the Zattere and the Grand Canal. It has been fully refurbished, with full elevator service, since 1996 for use as housing both for students attending local educational institutions and for tourists seeking shorter term accommodations. About 50 students live in another part of the building and have their own kitchen facilities. I was aware of their presence only occasionally. Usually one or two would pass through the lobby during breakfast laden with book bags, architectural drawings, and musical instruments. The number of tourists varies seasonally. The architects did a good job of integrating modern amenities with such an old structure, emphasizing light colors, contemporary furniture, and interesting juxtapositions of metal, stone, tile, and wood. The front door is a very stylish sheet of plate glass that slides silently to the side allowing you to enter a foyer clad in polished slabs of pale stone. Fortunately, I had committed the street number to memory. The entrance is so unobtrusive that one could easily miss it (when in doubt, look for the Hotel Belle Arti, which is next door). A single flight of stairs leads to the reception desk and lobby, where the dominant theme of terrazzo floors, honey-colored walls, and natural wood and stone trim is established. Very old stone columns, arched doorways, brick infill, etc., have been left exposed throughout the building to suggest its age. Black and white photographs in the lobby illustrate one of the Centerâ€™s former uses as a vocational training center for young boys from troubled homes in Venice. Carpentry, typesetting, and machining were among the trades taught throughout most of the twentieth century. I found the photographs somewhat haunting. Nowhere was there to be found a single person with a smile. Scattered throughout the building are various tools and products from this period. There is a particularly interesting set of typesetting apparatus near the elevator, for example. The reception desk is staffed by some very nice people, all of whom speak Italian, English, and at least one other language. Once again my feeble language skills were put to shame. I was given a room on the second floor and handed a key and a plastic card that when inserted in the data port in my room activated the lights and the heat. I kept the key during my stay but left the utility card at the desk when I went out and about for the day. My room was not particularly large, but it had a window overlooking the central courtyard, which contained a typical Venetian wellhead and would have held tables and chairs if the weather had been more clement. It also had a single bed (with a great mattress and immaculate bed linen), a bookshelf behind the head of the bed, an armoire, a desk, a chair, a mirror, a set of wall hooks, and a bench. All of these were carefully coordinated with one another to present a chic, modern appearance several steps above the level found in high-end dorms or conference centers. The hardware was particularly well made. To one side was a sliding door that opened to a private bathroom. This was a vision of ceramic tile and gleaming white porcelain fixtures with polished chrome fittings. A large heated towel rack was on the wall to the side of the sink, and a small, but lovely, shower with optional handheld shower head occupied the opposite corner. The sink had a shelf and mirror over it. The water pressure was rock solid, and there was plenty of piping hot water at all hours of the day and night. The entire room was so clean that it sparkled. Quite frankly, it was nicer than my bathroom at home. I was sad to leave it. A few toiletries were provided: small packages of soap and a packet of shampoo. There was a blow dryer on the wall. The towels were typical for Italy. They were made of very fine white linen, beautifully laundered, of the sort Americans might use for drying fine glassware or for placement in the powder room. There were no washcloths. I have encountered this arrangement all over Italy and have never found it satisfactory, so I packed my own terrycloth beach towel and about 14 washcloths. The towel I took home at the end of the trip. The washcloths, which were old and ready to be relegated to the rag pile, I disposed of as I traveled around Italy. Itâ€™s an excellent system. I would use it again. A telephone was beside the bed. There was a direct link to the reception desk and another to an outside line. Instructions were included for making international calls. There was a bedside wall-mounted lamp for reading in bed, and another ceiling light for general ambient light. The room was always warm and cozy, so important at that time of year in Venice (we had snow one day and chilling drizzle on several other days). I was especially appreciative of the warmth as I had spent the previous week in Florence being chilled to the bone in an 18th century palazzo. Life is so much more pleasant when you are warm enough. The room was cleaned each morning. The bed was made, and halfway through my stay the sheets were changed. There are a blanket and a bedspread on the bed as standard issue, and there is another blanket in the bottom of the armoire. I was always comfortably warm with this arrangement and used the spare blanket only as an exercise mat to do some sit-ups and stretching exercises. Fresh linens were placed in the bathroom; the sink was cleaned; the toilet paper replenished, etc., every day. I suspect that the floors were swept and/or damp mopped as well. In addition to the reception desk, the ground level contains the breakfast room, a TV room (which also has a computer with internet access); a small room with a couple of vending machines delivering cold and hot drinks, and a meeting room or two, which I never investigated. The breakfast area draws a lot of natural light from the interior courtyard and is fitted out with tables and chairs similar in design to the furniture found in the bedrooms. The effect is chic, minimalist, and highly functional. The standard Italian coffee machine dispenses several kinds of coffee, hot chocolate, and hot water for tea (which really isnâ€™t hot enough). There were teabags and packets of lemon juice nearby. Three kinds of cold cereal and two kinds of fruit juice were provided, along with milk. There was no fruit, but this is the sort of thing easily picked up around town and taken down to breakfast in the morning as desired. On a separate table was a beautiful array of baked goods, packets of butter, and at least six kinds of jam and honey. My favorite was the cornetto, which is found all over Italy, with slight regional variations. The Venice cornetto seems to be lower in fat content than the Florentine version. Itâ€™s very light and crispy and has a faint coating of powdered sugar. I usually ate two of these for breakfast at the Center and then had a cup of hot chocolate somewhere in my travels around 11 oâ€™clock in the morning. This sufficed quite nicely until lunch. Also available were: slices of panettone; slices of marbled chocolate breakfast bread (which I tried but did not care for); packets of light butter cookies, which reminded me of both Animal Crackers and the Danish butter cookies available at holiday time in the States; and packets of something akin to rice crackers or rye crisp. Many Americans will find this last item to be dry, tasteless, and thoroughly unsatisfying. I count myself among them. As nearly as I can determine, its sole function is to serve as a crunchy vehicle for butter and jam. I have seen it elsewhere in Italy, and I always steer clear of it. Itâ€™s not worth eating in my opinion, but you should try it for yourself at least once. I donâ€™t drink coffee or tea, but I found the accoutrements useful when I developed a cough and a slight cold towards the end of my stay. By combining hot water, two packets of lemon juice, and two packets of honey I was able to concoct a soothing drink for my throat every morning. I also took several packets of butter with me each morning and used them either at lunch or dinner around town for buttering bread. Breakfast is the only meal offered at the Center. It is a self-serve buffet, open from 7:30 to 9:30, seven days a week. I thought it was above average in comparison to other places I have stayed in Italy. Italian TV is widely considered to be the lowest form of television available anywhere in the world. I concur with this opinion, and thus I didnâ€™t make use of the TV room. I did use the internet connection once to check my e-mail. The charge was 2.50 euros for 15 minutes. There are also several internet cafes in the Dorsoduro sestiere, most notably in Campo Santa Margherita. I used the vending machines for cold carbonated drinks. The price was very reasonable, but the selection was limited. The location of the Center is one of its biggest attractions. There are two nearby vaporetto stops. One is Accademia, which is served by the #1 line, the slow boat making all stops up and down the Grand Canal, and also by the #81 line, the express boat making only selected stops up and down the Grand Canal, of which Accademia is one. The other stop is Zattere on the Giudecca Canal, served by a number of different lines. The Center is a walk of one or two minutes from either one, even with a suitcase in tow. Not as well known is the Centerâ€™s proximity to the Zattere stop of the Alilaguna boat service to Veniceâ€™s Marco Polo Airport. I had read about the service in a few guidebooks and had thought that it might be a wonderful way to enter or exit the city. However, I assumed that I would end up taking the airport shuttle bus from Piazzale Roma. Quite by accident I discovered the Alilaguna boats tied up at their Zattere loading dock one day and realized that I could hop on one of these and be at the airport with nothing more required than a one-minute walk from the Center. At the time of my trip the boats stopped at Zattere at 35 minutes past the hour, every hour. I took the 7:35 a.m. boat from Zattere, which made a number of stops along the way, and landed at the boat dock of the airport at 9 a.m. From there I caught a shuttle bus to the airport terminal itself and got in line at the Air France desk at 9:20 a.m. One should plan on a total of two hours travel time from the Zattere our of the morning. It was a treat, and I would do it again. In the immediate neighborhood are: an excellent bar of the Italian variety (meaning coffee, snacks, and some liquor); several trattorias (see my review of Trattoria San Trovaso elsewhere); several tabacchis for gum, candy, and sundries; several shops selling excellent sandwiches and snacks; Nicoâ€™s gelateria, which makes the best hot chocolate to be found in the Dorsoduro, certainly of a much higher quality than is issued in the bars; and all the services of Campo Santa Margherita, which is a 12-minute walk away. A short walk over the Accademia bridge opens up the rest of Venice to you. My bill for six nights came to 424 euros. I paid with two travelerâ€™s checks, each one in the amount of 200 euros, and some euro dollars. I was charged 4 euros for using the travelerâ€™s checks because the bank charges the Center that much for accepting travelerâ€™s checks. Even travelerâ€™s checks in euro denominations are very difficult to use in Italy. Nobody seems to like them, and the bank charge is the reason why. Any criticisms? Only a few. The broad expanses of terrazzo flooring and the long straight hallways make the Center a pleasure to use and a breeze to clean but also very noisy. Italians love to pound up and down the hallways in shoes with hard soles. Americans, the loudest nationality on the planet, love to converse at full voice outside anyoneâ€™s door at any hour. The architects failed to provide adequate soundproofing between rooms and tied the plumbing together in such a way that the most intimate bathroom activities of oneâ€™s upstairs neighbors can be heard clearly. The open-air central courtyard is still an unknown quantity. Because very few people were staying at the Center when I was there, the noise level was never overwhelming. At high season, it might get to me. Would I stay here again? Yes. The advantages far outweigh the disadvantages.

Reviews.Title: “Incredible Find”
Reviews.Author: wahoowa
Reviews.Content: My husband and I travelled to Italy on a budget this past May. This inn was an incredibly welcome respite from the normal "holes" that we stayed in while there. The reception area was spotless, the front desk people were extremely friendly, readily spoke english, held our luggage until check in, and provided welcome advice on where we were, what to see, and where to go. The rooms were spare but spotless and newly renovated, climate controlled, with HUGE bathrooms! Ours (and I think most) had windows facing an interior courtyard. We kept our window open all night (b/c in May we didn't need air conditioning) and didn't hear a peep. It was probably our first full nights sleep since we'd arrived. The location is EXCELLENT! About a 10 min walk to St. Mark's square and right around the corner from Accademia. Also, the main body of water is 1 block away (the adjoining church fronts the water). The best part about this is if you arrive by train or by air to Venice, both the train station and the airport have shuttles that stop right in front of this place. Go around the corner and head along the waterfront, and you'll find a neat little comunity with locals, away from the hustle of the well-beaten path to St. Marks. We felt like this was a little piece of paradise and wished we had stayed another night to really explore! The breakfast was pretty hearty, as far as Italian breakfasts go. Cereal, yogurt, OJ, coffee, breads, pastries and croissants. I thought the price (100E) was very good, considering we were in high season on a weekend and the quality of the accomodations. The previous night we arrived very late and stayed near the train station in this little hole-in-the-wall horrible horrible place for 90E, so I'd say this is a good deal for venice.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful Guest House”
Reviews.Author: Canvas
Reviews.Content: On our recent trip to Italy, while in Venice we stayed at the convent, Don Orione Artigianelli (web site www.donorione-venezia.it). We loved it! The rooms were very large and had very modern bathrooms ensuite. The whole guesthouse area looked as if it had recently been renovated and was spotless. The rooms did not have TV but did have a hair dryer. Curfew at night was 1:30 am, plenty late for us. The location was superb--near the Accademia and steps away from the boat stop at Zattere. We were within an easy walk to S. Marco. The breakfast was a typical bread and juice affair but they did have a variety of breads. One night, Father Paul escorted us to a nearby restaurant when we inquired of him about its location. He was especially nice. Although this is not the most inexpensive of alternatives in Venice, we felt that we got real value for our money by its size, cleanliness, location, and the hospitality that we encountered while we were guests. We highly recommend it and would want to stay there when we next go to Venice.

HotelInfo.Name: Centro Culturale Don Orione Artigianelli
